title: Jack Hampstead
text:
Jack Hampstead (1920-1992) was an Australian professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1940s and 1950s, and <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a>ed in the 1950s. A New South Wales state representative lock forward, he played in Sydney's <a href="NSWRFL%20Premiership">NSWRFL Premiership</a> for the <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain club</a>. Hampstead later became coach of the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown club</a>. His grandson is <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a> former referee <a href="Sean%20Hampstead">Sean Hampstead</a>.
Playing career.
Born in <a href="Sydney%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Sydney, New South Wales</a>, Hampstead played 108 first grade games between 1939 and 1951, playing , and later . He played in the premiership-winning Balmain teams of <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201944">1944</a> and <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201946">1946</a>.
Coaching.
For the <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201953">1953 season</a>, Hampstead became the <a href="Bulldogs%20Rugby%20League%20Football%20Club">Canterbury-Bankstown</a> coach. Of that year's eighteen matches, he won nine, and lost seven. However, in <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201954">1954</a> he lost fourteen of the eighteen, and won just four. He did not coach first-grade again.
Hampstead was a member of the <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain Tigers</a>' board until his death in 1992.
